Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Connecting the Dots: Using Radical-formation Control to Achieve Desired EB-initiated Polymer Properties

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
A joint academic-industrial partnership between the University of Iowa and ebeam Technologies (eT) is proposed to study fundamental science of electron beam curing of polymers. The work could eliminate the need for free-radical initiators in polymerization, help understand the mechanism of the initiation step by ebeam, and could lead to more uniform curing profiles. Electron-beam (EB) curing offers a faster, lower-power, and solvent-free means of polymerizing inks, films, coatings, and adhesives when compared to thermal drying and curing processes. The goal of this research project is to advance EB-curing technologies by developing structure-processing property relationships that incorporate the fundamental knowledge of how chemical structure influences radical formation and reactivity. This understanding will also enable the extension of EB-curing technologies to a wider range of applications, including high-performance materials for the automotive and aerospace industries and low-migration materials for the food and medical product industries.

The following research topics will be pursued: (1) correlation of the radiation yield with monomer structure, (2) comparison of property development in EB- and UV-cured systems having equal radical concentration, (3) control of crosslink density through monomer structure and composition, and (4) minimization of migration through monomer structure and composition. Kinetic rates and radical concentrations will be measured using spectroscopic techniques to obtain monomer initiation efficiencies. Molecular weight distributions (for linear polymers), crosslink density (for polymer networks), and mechanical properties will be measured using gel permeation chromatography and dynamic mechanical analysis to demonstrate the impact of initiation mechanism, monomer structures, and process parameters on polymer physical properties. Gas chromatography/mass spectrometry will be used to identify and quantify leachable materials and their diffusion coefficients for ultra-low-migration systems. Development of advanced relationships between EB kinetics and the resulting polymer properties may provide a level of understanding of EB-cured systems significantly beyond what is now available. In addition to training graduate students in an industrially-relevant area of study, outreach activities to K-12 and undergraduate students in STEM are planned based on polymer demonstrations incorporating project results. Special emphasis will be placed on recruiting underrepresented female and minority students to participate in this research project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramElement.Text: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Electron-beam (EB) curing offers a fast, low-energy, and solvent-free means of polymerizing inks, films, and coatings compared to thermal polymerization.  No initiator is required to form the free-radical active centers, making this technique especially appealing for packaging applications where molecular migration would be problematic.  The goal of this research is to advance EB technologies by increasing the fundamental understanding of the effects of chemical structure on radical formation and reactivity. Chemical modeling software was used to calculate the average energy required to form radicals on monomers via hydrogen abstraction. A library of monomer series was systematically developed to provide insight on how chemical structure influences radical formation so that experimental efforts could focus on the most promising candidates.  Dose rate effects (DREs) were explored in these monomer series, confirming DREs to be based on number and type of labile bond, not monomer size. Although the yield of primary (initial) radicals is independent of dose rate, the instantaneous concentration of those radicals is directly proportional to dose rate.  Finally, it was revealed that a non-reciprocity between dose rate and rate of polymerization results in DREs.  A new protocol was developed for comparing outcomes from EB and UV polymerization systems with equal primary radical concentrations. UV polymerized systems resulted in higher conversions, while EB polymerized systems were more highly crosslinked, demonstrating the differences in secondary radical reactions for each system.  While acrylate monomers polymerized well under either EB or UV irradiation, conversion of methacrylate monomers and mixtures with methacrylate monomers was substantially less or even zero. Additional studies revealed that methacrylate monomers formed just as many primary radicals as their acrylate monomer counterparts; however, those primary radicals do not convert to initiating radicals in the case of methacrylate monomers. Further comparisons were made between EB (high dose rate) and x-ray (low dose-rate) polymerization of acrylate and methacrylate monomers. In all cases, conversion of methacrylate monomers was on par with their acrylate monomer counterparts after x-ray irradiation.  The slower dose rate in x-ray systems most likely improves conversion outcomes since the lower radical density reduces termination and/or the propagation rate for these monomers aligns better with x-ray exposure times. Gel fraction measurements were used to develop relationships between the ratio of initiating radicals to primary radicals and the extent of crosslinking in EB-cured monomer mixtures. In acrylate mixtures, the relationship between crosslinking and formulation appears to be linear up to a threshold concentration, at which point it plateaus. In acrylate/methacrylate mixtures, the relationship is more complex and appears to depend on the reactivity ratios of the respective monomers. A migration cell assembly has been manufactured, and a preliminary protocol for testing migration in EB films has been outlined so that, once promising mixtures have been identified, their efficacy as low-migration materials can be evaluated. The fundamental information acquired provides a better understanding of the chemistry / processing conditions / polymer properties needed to advance EB technology in current and future applications.

Broader Impacts. Results from this research have been published in 7 peer-reviewed journal articles, 2 peer-reviewed technical magazine articles, and 5 (inter)national conference proceedings.  Results were also presented at over 20 local, regional, and (inter)national meetings (e.g., ACS, AIChE, ICIP, and RadTech annual conferences, as well as UI Research Open Houses and MSU Undergraduate Research Symposia).  Five pre-graduate students, half of whom are from underrepresented groups, participated in research associated with this project, including a male undergraduate and a female high school student who completed summer internships at PCT. Students presented their research results at local, regional, and national student conferences, and 2 students completed their engineering honors theses based on project work.  Three graduate students completed work on the project, 1 of whom had started on the project as an undergraduate student. The female Ph.D. student based her dissertation on this work and was hired by Intel after graduation. In addition, the results have been used to augment outreach for hundreds of K-12 students in eastern Iowa, western Illinois, northeastern Mississippi, and across the US. As the MSU AIChE faculty advisor, the PI helped the student chapter deliver polymer-based, hands-on demonstrations at various outreach events, including the AIChE K-12 STEM Showcase at Annual Student Conferences, Girl Scouts STEM Badge Days for K-12 girls, STEAM Mondays at a local library, and engineering outreach at various local elementary schools and after-school programs. The PI also collaborated with graphic arts professors to assist art students in understanding radiation-induced polymerization and its importance, resulting in art students receiving the top awards for their RadTech poster submissions, which were publicized internationally.

Images (1 of )
  • Conversion profiles for an acrylate (POEA) and its analogous methacrylate (POEMA) via EB (A) and x-ray (B) initiation. Although EB initiation results in much faster acrylate reactions, x-ray initiation results in higher final conversion for both the acrylate and methacrylate.
    Sage Schissel, Finnis Ginder, Nicole Thiher, Julie Jessop
    Copyrighted
    Julie L Jessop
    Figure 2
  • Conversion profiles for an UV- and EB-initiated acrylate, PEA (A), and its analogous methacrylate, PEMA (B). UV initiation results in faster reactions and higher final conversion compared to initiation with EB for PEA, while PEMA is essentially unreactive for both UV and EB initiation. Not
    Nicole Thiher, Sage Schissel, Julie Jessop
    Copyrighted
    Julie L Jessop
    Figure 1
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Intellectual Merit. Electron-beam (EB) curing offers a fast, low-energy, and solvent-free means of polymerizing inks, films, and coatings compared to thermal polymerization. No initiator is required to form the free-radical active centers, making this technique especially appealing for packaging applications where molecular migration would be problematic. Chemical modeling software was used to calculate the average energy required to form radicals on monomers via hydrogen abstraction.
